occurrences.line_text: Before their rage grew to so great vnrest,
Him to auenge, before his bloud were cold,
That nought but death before his eyes he saw,
And euer burning wrath before him laid,
Which still before him she remou'd away,
And one sate wayting euer them before,
Present before the maiestie diuine,
The cloudes before him fled for terrour great,
To let them downe before his flightes end:
Whylome, before that cursed Dragon got
Since late she saw him fall before his enemy.
Whom farre before did march a goodly band
And him before themselues prostrating low,
And them before, the fry of children young
From point to point, as is before exprest,
Till fast before the king he did alight;
He was affiaunced long time before,
Singing before th'eternall maiesty,
Before her standing she espied had,
Before, behind, and round about him layes:
Your selfe of sword before that bloudy day:
Before they fastned were vnder her knee
Before her gate high God did Sweat ordaine,
By the hoare lockes, that hong before her eyes,
On his horse necke before the quilted sell,
Before her sonne could well assoyled bee,
Into the land, that lay them faire before,
Such as he saw, she gan him lay before,
Cymochles, that had neuer met before
All these before the gates of Pluto lay,
Before the dore sat selfe-consuming Care,
As eye of man did neuer see before;
Such grace now to be happy, is before thee laid.
Another blis before mine eyes I place,
That liuing eye before did neuer see:
And farre before a light-foot Page did flie,
Who Guyons shield cast euer him before,
The cloudes, as things affrayd, before him flye;
With greater fury, then before was found;
The one before, by which all in did pas,
Yet true it is, that long before that day
Which him before, that sacred seate did fill,
Early before the Morne with cremosin ray,
Which fled a sunder, and him fell before,
And raysd him vp much stronger then before,
For here before a perlous passage lyes,
Or wrathfull Neptune did them driue before
And brought to ground, that neuer wast before;
But faire before the gate a spatious plaine,
That none of all the sixe before, him durst assay.
Ne byte before, but rome from place to place,
As did this knight, before ye hither came.
Which two did yield, before she did them smight.
And him in euery part before her fashioned.
Yet him in euery part before she knew,
But he it knew at home before he hard
Earely the morrow next, before that day
Before that Merlin dyde, he did intend,
Then euer him before or after liuing wight.
In the last field before Meneuia
Few dayes before, had gotten a great pray
Him so transfixed she before her bore
And his sweete lips, on which before that stownd
But hurt his hart, the which before was sound,
Such as the Angels weare before Gods tribunall.
That had not her thereof before auized,
As doth the lilly fresh before the sunny ray.
But all the day before the sunny rayes
A little boate lay houing her before,
She bore before her lap a dolefull Squire,
The inward smoke, that did before but steeme,
Forth marched to a Castle them before,
And now so long before the wicket fast
Was her before, and Paridell besyde;
Before that angry Gods, and cruell skye
Who long before the ten yeares siege of Troy,
That was by him cald Paros, which before
To quench the flames, which she had tyn'd before,
And seem'd more grieuous, then it was before:
And bad before his soueraine Lord appere:
And comming him before, low louted on the lay.
She wonneth in the forrest there before.
Before ye enterprise that way to wend:
Early before the heauens fairest light
Ne scarsely who before: like as a Beare
Her ample shield she threw before her face,
Holding a lattice still before his face,
And her before the vile Enchaunter sate,
Before faire Britomart, she fell prostrate,
Now gan to feede on hope, which she before
All bent to mirth before the bride was bedded,
Seest not the Ladie there before thy face?
Are wont, before they may to heauen flie,
Before that they in blisse amongst the Gods were plaste.
Where they before them found in fresh aray
Cambello it away before had got:
And make his praise before his owne preferd:
Vpon them fell, before her timely howre;
He held the Lady forth before him right,
To come and shew themselues before the light,
There she alighting, fell before her feet,
Before misfortune did his hew deface:
Bearing a litle Dwarfe before his steed,
Him ouertooke, before he came in vew.
Ouer his head, before the harme came neare.
His head before him tombling on the ground.
Then was I taken and before her brought:
Before the ryder, as he captiue were,
Before that Castle was an open plaine,
And her before was seated ouerthwart
Before that day her wooed to his bed;
And all the way before them as they went,
Triton his trompet shrill before them blew,
Before the spouse: that was Arion crownd;
But him before there went, as best became
And let their swelling waters low before him fall.
And her before there paced Pages twaine,
Which neuer she before disclosd to none,
And mourn'd to see her losse before her eyne,
And on her knee before him falling lowe,
Liftes vp his head, that did before decline
And gins to spread his leafe before the faire sunshine.
All th'East before vntam'd did ouerronne,
It was not long, before he ouertooke
To beare that Ladies head before his breast.
But he was well aware, and leapt before his fall.
They saw before them, far as they could vew,
But here and there before his presence flew,
And there before them stood a Coffer strong,
Two Ilands, which ye there before you see
Before which time I lou'd, as was my lot,
Through all the fields and vallies did before him flie.
Made them all enter in before her sight,
Before the city gate, in open sight;
Whom when he saw before his foote prostrated,
He wilfull lost, that he before attayned.
And put before his lap a napron white,
As if before she had not counted trew.
It was not long, before she heard the sound
Vppon her speare she bore before her breast,
Whose like before she neuer saw nor red;
Him selfe before her feete he lowly threw,
Who long before awoke (for she ful ill
To lay his spoiles before his lemans traine:
Before two Knights, that after her did speed
Till that at length she did before her spie
His other fellow Pagan, which before him past.
Before directed by his Lord; to th'end
And comming full before his horses vew,
But th'onely feare, that was before their vew;
So on a tree, before the Tyrants dore,
And many pleasant trickes before her show,
And round about, before her feet there sate
Who bowing low before her Maiestie,
Euen foule Adulterie her face before,
In their first flowre, before this fatall teene
Then famous Niobe, before she tasted
And all his way before him still prepare.
To him he hath, before this Castle greene,
Seeing that sad ensample them before,
He sternely marcht before the Castle gate,
Behinde, beside, before, as he it list apply.
Before his feete, in all that peoples sight;
For that he weeneth well, before that tide
A rout of people they before them kend,
And made him oftentimes in field before me fall.
To leaue the loue, that ye before embraced,
Appointed for Irenas death before,
Yet the huge stroke, which he before intended,
Atchieu'd so hard a quest, as few before;
The morrow next, before the lampe of light,
But when he saw his foe before in vew,
Preuented him before his stroke could light,
But saue my life, which lot before your foot doth lay.
Before his feet her selfe she did proiect,
Whose fellow he before had sent apart;
Vntimely dyde, before I did attaine
The day before by iust auengement
There him befell, vnlooked for before,
Which at the first before it had infected,
But th'other not so swift, as she before,
What meaneth this, which here I see before?
Her stubborne hart, which loue before disdayned,
Saued but two, yet in two yeares before,
Were bound about, and voyded from before,
(That was that courteous Knight, whom he before
Or else abide the death, that hard before you stands.
This bottle thus before you with such toile,
The Damzell was before the altar set,
Fly like a flocke of doues before a Faulcons vew.
For feare of wetting them before their bed;
Whose like before his eye had neuer seene,
Before the feete of the faire Pastorell;
Whom they before in diuerse spoyles had caught:
Should with the rest be sold before him theare,
Ne stayeth leaue to take, before his friends doe dye.
This dismall day, and was not dead before,
Before I saw faire Pastorella dye.
So forth they goe together (God before)
And also all those flockes, which they before
But she whose sides before with secret wound
But closing it againe like as before,
To mortall men, then he had done before;
Emongst them ran, and falling them beforne,
And th'vnacquainted light began to feare:
Which hearing his rash Syre, began to rend
At last when fayling breath began to faint,
Since errant armes to sew he first began;
And at his first arriuall, them began
Then she began a treatie to procure,
From lofty siege began these words aloud to sound.
Got from great Atlas daughters, hence began,
Since he this hardie enterprize began:
Whose tender bud to blossome new began,
That he began to doubt his dazeled sight,
That he began to faint, and life decay:
Of his creation, when he life began,
And snatching his bright sword began to close
He bad tell on; and then she thus began.
The bud of youth to blossome faire began,
When so the froward skye began to lowre:
Then Paridell began to chaunge his theme,
But being past, he thus began amaine;
Her cause of comming she to tell began.
She then began them humbly to intreate,
And euermore, when he began to winke,
Began to peepe aboue this earthly masse,
The Prince halfe rapt, began on her to dote:
Began to doubt, when she them saw embrace,
Began to faint, and feele their corage cold.
Began to spring which shortly grew full great,
Each one did flie; their hearts began to faile,
When they thus ended had, the Knight began;
Came forth into the rout, and them t'array began.
The Trumpets sounded, and the field began;
With bitter strokes it both began, and ended.
And to her turning, thus began againe;
There she began to make her monefull plaint
But soone as he began to lay about
Began the streight conditions to propound,
Then Zele began to vrge her punishment,
When one in armes she saw, began to fly;
With his huge flaile began to lay about;
He drawing neare, began to greete them faire,
Those knights began a fresh them to assayle,
At him began aloud to barke and bay,
Began to quake and tremble with dismay;
There then began a fearefull cruell fray
Betwixt you two began this strife and sterne vprore.
Vnto his Inne began to draw apace;
That euen his ruder hart began to rew,
Then thus began the lamentable Dame;
And in his homely wize began to assay
To these sicke twaine, that now began to droupe,
She starting vp, began to shrieke aloud,
Began to tremble euery limbe and vaine;
And night arriued hard at hand, began
He thus began: Where shall I then commence
Began to mitigate his swelling sourse,
Began some smacke of comfort new to tast,
Of whom he did great Constantine beget,
For vertues onely sake, which doth beget
Of that commixtion they did then beget
Begets and eke conceiues, ne needeth other none.
With balefull beggerie, or foule disgrace,
And with new day new worke at once begin:
Like to an holy Monck, the seruice to begin.
At last recouering hart, he does begin
Begin, and end the bitter balefull stound;
Each goodly thing is hardest to begin,
Must now anew begin, like race to runne;
Tho to him louting lowly, did begin
Must first begin, and well her amenage:
Who first to rayse our house to honour did begin.
Is layd, they fiercely then begin to shoure,
Begin then, ï¿½ my dearest sacred Dame,
Begin, ï¿½ Clio, and recount from hence
The hard begin, that meets thee in the dore,
For so must all things excellent begin,
Our life is day, but death with darknesse doth begin.
Tho gan the battell freshly to begin;
Ere that we to efforce it do begin:
For discord harder is to end then to begin.
Abate, and panting breath begin to fayle,
Then doe the saluage beasts begin to play
Her to receiue, till time they should begin the fight.
There then a piteous slaughter did begin:
But where ye ended haue, now I begin
Which ended, then his bloudy banket should beginne.
And in my woes beginner it to end:
The carefull cold beginneth for to creepe,
He first her hands beginneth to vnbind,
In their beginning they are weake and wan,
Though strange beginning had, yet fixed is
Great matter growing of beginning small;
Thereby to make their loues beginning, their liues end.
For her beginning a more fearefull fray,
Which gaue beginning to her woe and wretchednesse.
Well hoped I, and faire beginnings had,
Soone as thy dreadfull trompe begins to sownd;
But now my teme begins to faint and fayle,
Towards the westerne brim begins to draw,
Begins to turne, and sunne to shine more bright,
That wicked band of villeins fresh begon
Was greatly woe begon, and gan to feare,
But was as farre at last, as when I first begon.
And what was she her selfe so woe begone,
To die againe? all ends that was begonne.
Affiance made, my happinesse begonne,
In plainer wise to tell her grieuaunce she begonne.
Which I to proue, this voyage haue begonne.
Things oft impossible (quoth she) seeme, ere begonne.
But loue, that is in gentle brest begonne,
But wondrously begotten, and begonne
That their faire guest was gone, they both begonne
At those proud words that other knight begonne
Tho forth the Boaster marching, braue begonne
As if but then the battell had begonne:
For he last ended, hauing first begonne.
As if but then the battell had begonne,
That harder may be ended, then begonne.
Which with so strong attempt I had begonne.
There Iustice first her princely rule begonne.
Where what ensu'd, shall in next Canto be begonne.
As fiercely yet, as when he first begonne,
To whome in sort, as he at first begonne,
Will in an other Canto better be begonne.
Did waite about it, gaping griesly all begor'd.
Which wast begot in Dï¿½mogorgons hall,
But whence they sprong, or how they were begot,
There he this knight of her begot, whom borne
Which wast begot in heauen, but for thy bad
But wondrously they were begot, and bred
Whilome begot, being but halfe twin of that berth.
Anchyses sonne begot of Venus faire,
Which that great Gyant Blomius begot,
Litae, by him begot in loues delight,
Of Cerberus whilome he was begot,
Begot of foule Echidna, as in bookes is taught.
By him begot of faire Eurynome,
And there begotten of a Lady myld,
Begotten by her kingly Paramoure,
Fiue sonnes he left begotten of one wife,
But wondrously begotten, and begonne
Begotten by two fathers of one mother,
Orthrus begotten by great Typhaon,
Be gotten, not begotten, which should drinke
Suffers her selfe through sleepe beguild to bee,
Beguild thus with delight of nouelties,
His face, was with the loue thereof beguild;
Led with delight, they thus beguile the way,
Him to beguile of griefe and agony:
Those guestes beguiled, did beguile their eyes
So goodly did beguile the Guyler of the pray.
Illusion, that did beguile his sense,
Such as ye haue him boasted, to beguile
And thought so to beguile her grieuous smart;
And fed on fodder, to beguile her sight.
The better to beguile, whom she so fond did finde.
Was nigh beguiled with so goodly sight:
Her mournefull plaintes, beguiled of her art,
Of that good knight, his late beguiled guest:
My lifest Lord she thus beguiled had;
Those guestes beguiled, did beguile their eyes
And his slow eyes beguiled of their sight,
Being likewise beguiled in her thought,
Conceiued close in her beguiled hart,
And then againe begun, My weaker yeares
And well begun end all so well, I pray,
Euen in the dore him meeting, she begun;
In loue were either ended or begunne:
He soone her lost: wherefore he now begunne
The knight was wrath to see his stroke beguyld,
Being thereof beguyld was fild with new affright.
Euen so Clarinda her owne Dame beguyld,
And Hellenors both eyes did eke beguyle,
And then, her griefe with errour to beguyle,
Gan forth to lay his bayte her to beguyle,
The birds to catch, or fishes to beguyle:
And also of their priuate loues beguyled;
By her beguyled, and confounded quight:
And doubting to be wronged, or beguyled,
In the behalfe of wronged weake did fight:
And purchase honour in his friends behalue,
Which vnto any knight behappen may
And thereto did himselfe right well behaue,
First, that ye better shall your selfe behaue
Towards all womenkind them kindly to behaue.
This gentle knight himselfe so well behaued,
Behaues with cares, cannot so easie mis.
For in his speeches and behauiour hee
Her light behauiour, and loose dalliaunce
With daily shew of courteous kind behauiour,
Greatly confused in behauioure;
Gainst natures law, and good behauioure:
and learnes her wise beheast.
That his beheast they feared, as tyrans law,
The waues obedient to their beheast,
So litle did they hearken to her sweet beheast.
And sternly gan repine at his beheast;
High Gods beheast, and powre of holy lawes;
To him assynd, her high beheast to doo,
Did taste the bloud, obaying natures first beheast.
Did gladly hearken to his graue beheast,
Vnmyndfull of his vow and high beheast,
Taught to obay their bestiall beheasts,
We both are bound to follow heauens beheasts,
And to all people did diuide her dred beheasts.
And stared sterne on all, that him beheld,
That when the knight beheld, his mightie shild
The royall Virgin, which beheld from farre,
Which when the knights beheld, amazd they were,
Ilate beheld, and had not greater grace
Which when the carle beheld, and saw his guest
Where when that fairest Vna she beheld,
Whom so dismayd when that his foe beheld,
And his deare Ladie, that beheld it all,
So she beheld those maydens meriment
Speake they, which haue beheld the battailes, which it wan.
So when her goodly visage he beheld,
Still as he stood, faire PhÃ¦dria, that beheld
He there beheld, too long here to be told:
Whenas those knights beheld, with rare delight,
Whom when the knights beheld, they gan dispose
Had not his gentle Squire beheld his paine,
Ne euer land beheld, ne liuing wight,
And trembled, as them passing they beheld:
Which when those knights beheld, with scornefull eye,
Late dayes ensample, which these eyes beheld,
Which when the Prince beheld, a lothfull sight,
But when she better him beheld, she grew
Still whenas he beheld the heauenly Mayd,
Who soone as she beheld that suddein stound,
Which whenas Satyrane beheld, in hast
Which whenas they beheld, they smitten were
Which they far off beheld from Troian toures,
Whom when as Britomart beheld behind
Beheld her, all were with amazement smit,
Whom when as Paridel more plaine beheld,
Which when his other companie beheld,
Which when as Blandamour beheld, he sayd,
Beheld, eftsoones it prickt his wanton mind
And when at last she had beheld her fill,
Whom when on ground his brother next beheld,
They which that piteous spectacle beheld,
Which when as all the lookers on beheld,
All which, when gentle Canacee beheld,
Beheld, he woxe therewith displeased sore,
Which when they all beheld they chaft and rag'd,
And hauing long beheld, at last enquired
Beheld, whereas he stood not farre aside,
Beheld the louely face of Artegall,
But euer when his visage she beheld,
But drawing nigh, ere he her well beheld;
Whom when the Prince beheld, he gan to rew
Which when that Squire beheld, he woxe full glad
Whom soone as faire AEmylia beheld,
Who all the while beheld their wrathfull moode,
Whom when the Briton Prince a farre beheld
Nor happie howre, beheld with gazefull eye,
Whom soone as I beheld, my hart gan throb,
And cruell shafts emblazond she beheld,
Who soone as he beheld that angels face,
There they beheld a mighty Gyant stand
Which when as Marinell beheld likewise,
Which when as all that present were, beheld,
Whom soone as he beheld, he knew, and thus behight.
By chaunce beheld, he left the bloudy slaughter,
Had long beheld, her selfe vppon the land
To haue beheld a spectacle so bad:
Beheld, it much appald her troubled spright:
And sternely him beheld with grim and ghastly looke.
She comming forth, when as she first beheld
Then all the people, which beheld that day,
Beheld, they her rebuked and vpbrayded sore.
With dreadfull looke he Artegall beheld,
Which haynous sight when Calidore beheld,
The sad Briana, which all this beheld:
When he beheld the streames of purple blood
Which when that Squire beheld, he to them stept,
Beheld, eftsoones he all enraged grew,
Whose cruell handling when that Squire beheld,
Which she beheld with lamentable eye,
Beheld two such, of two such villaines thrall,
Which when the Prince beheld, there standing by,
Meane while the Saluage man, when he beheld
There I beheld such vainenesse, as I neuer thought.
With lustfull eyes, beheld that louely guest,
There she beheld, that sore her grieu'd to see,
With forced fury following his behest,
But me had warnd old Timons wise behest,
Gan him instruct in euery good behest,
During which time, in euery good behest
But the swift bird obayd not her behest,
That in atchieuement of her high behest,
And made vnfit to serue his lawlesse mindes behest.
To her faire presence, and discrete behests.
Liagore, much praisd for wise behests;
Restraines those sterne behests, and cruell doomes of his.
Whereof the keyes are to thy hand behight
